Introduction

This article covers the cytoskeleton, a scaffolding system composed of filamentous proteins that enable biophysical actions such as vesicle transport, motility, and cell division.  There are 3 major cytoskeletal elements (

figure 1
):



  • Microfilaments (made of actin) are thin, flexible fibers involved in cell shape and motility.
  • Intermediate filaments (made of keratin, vimentin, and other proteins) are strong, ropy fibers that provide mechanical strength.
  • Microtubules (made of tubulin) are rigid, hollow tubes used as tracks for intracellular transport, organelle positioning, and mitosis.


In addition, the spectrin meshwork is also often considered with these elements.

Microfilaments

Function



Microfilaments are composed of polymerized actin monomers forming 2 intertwined strands (F-actin).  They are highly concentrated beneath the plasma membrane (ie, cortical actin) and participate in cell:



  • Shaping (eg, microvilli).
  • Locomotion (eg, lamellipodia and filopodia for crawling).
  • Contraction (eg, sarcomeres).
  • Cytoplasmic partitioning (eg, endocytosis, exocytosis, budding) and mitotic cleavage (ie, cytokinesis).


Actin-binding proteins regulate polymerization (eg, profilin), branching (eg, Arp2/3 complex), and severing (eg, cofilin).  Calcium-dependent actin-myosin interactions drive myocyte contraction.



DysfunctionDefects in actin regulation impair key cellular functions across multiple tissues:



  • In immune cells, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is a primary immunodeficiency due to WAS gene mutations that lead to defective actin branching.  This impairs T-cell synapse formation, leukocyte chemotaxis, and megakaryocyte fragmentation (to form platelets).  Manifestations include recurrent infections, thrombocytopenia, and secondary eczema (due to Th2 imbalance).
  • In neurons, axonal transport, dendritic remodeling, and neurotransmitter release rely, to varying extents, on dynamic actin rearrangement.  Dysfunction can lead to impaired neural signaling.
  • In epithelial tissue, actin contributes to cell junction stability and wound repair.  Abnormal actin regulation delays wound closure and weakens junctional integrity, which may predispose to barrier dysfunction and poor regenerative capacity.

Intermediate filaments

Function



Intermediate filaments are strong, rope-like fibers that handle mechanical stress, particularly in cells that need to resist deformation (eg, connective tissue, skin, neurons).  Unlike microfilaments or microtubules, which actively polymerize and depolymerize to change cell morphology, intermediate filaments are static and serve a purely structural role.  They stabilize the cytoplasmic architecture and anchor organelles in place.  Different cells have different intermediate filament proteins:



  • Epithelia use cytokeratin (eg, stratum corneum).
  • Mesenchymal cells use vimentin (eg, fibroblasts).
  • Myocytes use desmin (eg, cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle).
  • Astrocytes (support cells for neurons) use glial acid fibrillary protein (GFAP).
  • All nucleated cells use lamin (for the nuclear envelope).

Dysfunction



Defects in these intermediate filament proteins lead to loss of tissue integrity.



  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is caused by mutations in cytokeratin (eg, skin fragility and intraepidermal blistering with minor trauma).
  • Nuclear laminopathies involve mutations in lamin-A and lamin-C and include Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (eg, cardiomyopathy, skeletal muscle degeneration, premature joint contractures) and Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome (eg, accelerated aging with early-onset vascular disease and osteoporotic fractures).
  • Several genetic cardiomyopathies (both hypertrophic and dilated) involve mutations in desmin or lamin (in addition to sarcomeric proteins such as titin, myosin, and troponin).

Microtubules

Function



Microtubules are hollow cylinders made of alpha- and beta-tubulin dimers.  Microtubules perform the "heavy lifting" within the cell.  Microtubule polymerization and depolymerization depend on guanosine triphosphate hydrolysis, which releases more energy than ATP and enables greater mechanical work.  They also have a polarity (ie, positive and negative ends), which defines the direction of movement.  In particular, microtubules:



  • Serve as cargo tracks for motor proteins such as kinesin (moves toward the positive end) and dynein (moves toward the negative end).  The cargo can be vesicles or even whole organelles (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Form mitotic spindles for chromosome segregation (emanating from organizing centers at opposite ends of the cell, known as centrosomes, each containing 2 centrioles).
  • Forms cilia in the respiratory tract, fallopian tubes, and spermatozoa (where they are called flagella).  The cilia consist of 9 outer microtubules arranged around 2 inner core microtubules (9 + 2) (
    figure 3
    ).  The microtubules are linked to dynein arms, allowing the cilia to beat in unison and in the same direction.

Dysfunction



Defective microtubule transport causes a wide range of pathologies known as ciliopathies.



  • Primary ciliary dyskinesias are a group of disorders caused by mutations in dynein, resulting in loss of ciliary beating or coordination.  Manifestations include Kartagener syndrome, which involves bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis (due to mucostasis causing bacterial overgrowth and recurrent infections), and situs inversus (due to loss of leftward flow of embryonic extracellular fluid).  Infertility is common due to immotile sperm and impaired ovum migration in the fallopian tube.
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney diseases are a group of disorders, mostly due to mutations in polycystin, a ciliary protein involved in renal tubular fluid flow and nephron organization.  Manifestations include the formation of large bilateral renal cysts (dilated nephrons) and extrarenal dilations (eg, hepatic cysts, colonic diverticulosis, cerebral berry aneurysms).
  • Retinal ciliopathies include Leber congenital amaurosis and some forms of retinitis pigmentosa, which are caused by mutations in genes essential for the transport of opsin and retinal pigment within photoreceptor cells.  Manifestations include either congenital blindness or loss of vision early in childhood.


Microtubule inhibitors are effective chemotherapy agents because they cause M-phase arrest (

figure 4
).  Tubulin polymerization is inhibited by vinca alkaloids (eg, vinblastine, vincristine), so spindles cannot form (mnemonic: "Vinny never builds").  Conversely, depolymerization is inhibited by taxanes (eg, paclitaxel, docetaxel), so spindles are frozen in place (mnemonic: "taxes never go away").  Disruption of microtubule function impairs axonal transport in neurons, leading to length-dependent peripheral neuropathy, the most common adverse effect of these drugs.



In addition to chemotherapy, several other drugs also inhibit polymerization to block the M phase in neutrophils (eg, colchicine), fungal cells (eg, griseofulvin), or helminthic parasites (eg, mebendazole).

Spectrin meshwork

Function



The spectrin meshwork is a flexible, 2-dimensional pentagonal and hexagonal lattice (like the surface of a soccer ball) just below the cell surface, and it is attached to actin filaments via accessory proteins such as spectrin alpha/beta, ankyrin, dystrophin, and protein 4.1.  The spectrin mesh is particularly important in:



  • Red blood cells, where it prevents cell membranes from being stripped as cells pass through narrow capillaries and splenic sinuses.
  • Skeletal muscle, where it anchors the actin cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix to distribute mechanical stress evenly during muscle contraction.

Dysfunction



Spectrin defects result in hereditary spherocytosis, in which progressive membrane loss leads to spherical (rather than biconcave) red blood cells.  The spherocytes are less deformable and become trapped in the spleen, where they are destroyed (ie, extravascular hemolysis).



Dystrophin is a large protein in the spectrin family that links the actin cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix to minimize shear stresses and protect against contraction-induced muscle injury.  Loss of dystrophin in Duchenne or Becker muscular dystrophy results in microtears, calcium influx, and myocyte necrosis, causing the muscle body to be replaced by fibrofatty tissue.

Summary



The cytoskeleton is a dynamic scaffold that regulates cell shape and provides motor structures for cell movement, division, and intracellular vesicle traffic.  It comprises 3 major constituents: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.  Microfilaments (made of actin) mediate cell shape, motility, and contraction.  Defects in actin polymerization most famously result in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a primary immunodeficiency.  Intermediate filaments (made of various cell-specific proteins) provide tensile strength and support.  Defective intermediate filament proteins include nuclear laminopathies (eg, progeria), skin fragility, and heritable cardiomyopathies.  Microtubules (made of tubulin) are critical for cilia formation, vesicle and organelle movement, and mitotic spindle assembly.  Microtubule dysfunction causes ciliopathies, a group of conditions that include Kartagener syndrome and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.  Microtubule-targeting drugs (eg, vinca alkaloids, taxanes) arrest cells in mitosis but also cause length-dependent peripheral neuropathy due to disrupted axonal transport.  The spectrin meshwork, often considered part of the cytoskeletal system, reinforces the plasma membrane in erythrocytes and muscle cells.  Defective spectrin proteins (eg, ankyrin, dystrophin) lead to hereditary spherocytosis and Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
